title: Cat. 51.3  Noa Noa (Fragrant), 1893/94
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Noa Noa (Fragrant), from the Noa Noa Suite  
1893/94  
Fourth state of four  
Wood-block print in black ink, with touches of reddish-brown watercolor and black ink, over yellow-ink tone block and transferred golden-yellow, orange, and green oil-based media, some containing beeswax and conifer resin (probably pine resin), on cream Japanese paper, laid down on heavy cream wove card; 358 × 205 mm (max.) (image/primary/secondary support)  
Inscribed in the artist’s hand verso, lower left, in pen and brown ink: 10 Mars / PG [0 changed to 5 and a second rs added on top of the rs in black ink]  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Clarence Buckingham Collection, 1948.255  
Guérin 17, Kornfeld 13 III/III, B  
For the verso, see fig. 51.3.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">One of the most inventive printing campaigns of the late nineteenth century, Gauguin’s Noa Noa Suite distinguishes itself as an enterprise in which the artist worked freely and experimentally with a wide range of papers, disparate media, and unconventional printing and transfer techniques to produce a multitude of impressions. Having purchased ten end-grain boxwood blocks of the highest quality, suitable for both wood engraving with a needle and wood carving with variously shaped gouges and knives, the artist printed all ten blocks as a group at several distinct moments in the block-carving process. He did so in a series of working campaigns, in which he would print the blocks, then revise them, and then print them again. Different methods and materials were used in each campaign. These include applications of transparent watercolor washed over printed images; site-specific transfer of opaque, resinous, and waxy media from sheets of glass onto the paper before printing; and multiple, deliberately off-register printings in various inks on single sheets of paper. Close examination of a large number of examples has led to a chronology of print production that chronicles the artist’s more rudimentary printing methods as well as unconventional printing techniques in which atypical materials were used at different moments in the evolution of the suite.

Gauguin’s ingenuity is nowhere better represented than in the group of prints that he produced by combining traditional wood-block printing methods with complex media-transfer techniques, as seen in this fourth-state impression. After satisfactorily arriving at a final composition on the block, the artist focused his efforts on printing multilayered applications of color using more customary oil-based media, as well as some that contain beeswax and conifer resin (probably pine resin) in one layer, colored printing inks in another, and black and colored inks in one or more printings of the block on top of them.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 51.3.2).

RTI captures the work of art lit from multiple angles to enhance the surface topography of the wood-block print (fig. 51.3.3).

Four different layers of media are present in this impression of Noa Noa (Fragrant). Chrome yellow ink was applied first by transfer from another source, traditionally called a tone block, but instead it is likely that Gauguin used a piece of glass in this instance. The printing ink in this layer has a rather fluid appearance and was applied to localized areas on the block. The second layer of oil-based media combines traces of emerald green (est.), chrome yellow, and orange (a mixture of chrome yellow and vermilion) (see fig. 51.3.4). It was applied to specific areas directly on the paper by means of transfer from a piece of glass. However, this layer of medium has a thick, caked appearance indicative of the wax and resin it contains. Atop these two layers of colored media, the block was printed in black ink that is a mixture of carbon black and Prussian blue (trace amounts of vermilion are also present, likely from the red medium underlying the black ink in the area analyzed) (fig. 51.3.5). Gauguin completed the print with final touches of reddish-brown watercolor and black ink that he applied sparingly with a dry brush.

The paper is a good-quality, medium-weight Japanese paper that has a uniform distribution of long paper fibers that are visible under magnification. The sheet was mounted onto a secondary support, and the edges are all irregularly cut with a sharp edge rather than hand torn. The trimming of the sheet extends into the printed image quite significantly, especially in the lower left corner. The opacity of the thick secondary support makes it impossible to glean any information in transmitted light; however, the fibrous quality of the paper is enhanced when the sheet is viewed in transmitted light.

The impression is laid down on a piece of sturdy cream wove card. The artist mounted the print onto a heavier support for presentation purposes. However, at some point the mount was cut down well into the image area so that it is no longer visible from the front. Careful examination of the delaminated edges confirms that the card is of a type that Gauguin used to mount a number of his works on paper. The card stock contains numerous blue fibers that are dispersed throughout. Mounts of this type are extant on a number of prints from Gauguin’s Noa Noa Suite (see fig. 51.3.1).

358 × 205 mm (max.) (image/primary/secondary support)

This impression of Noa Noa evolved through a series of four stages. The media were applied in several layers. The various contours of their surfaces were fully assessed by means of surface shape studies undertaken at the Art Institute using RTI methods adapted for use with photometric stereo to reveal textural characteristics that often elude detection in normal light. Multiple images captured from a fixed camera position, lit from multiple specific angles, were combined to create an interactive composite image of the topography of the paper that reveals the manner in which the various media sit on the surface of the paper (see fig. 51.3.3). The bottom layer of chrome yellow media was applied overall by means of transfer from another source, traditionally called a tone block, to establish the base tone. This source could have been another piece of paper or another wood block; however, it is more likely that Gauguin used a piece of glass for this purpose. The medium appears to have been applied in a very fluid consistency. Its even appearance and uniform dispersion onto the sheet and into the paper fibers, as well as the absence of any secondary paper texture, point to the use of a solid support for transfer. However, there are several areas where the tone of the Japanese paper remains visible and devoid of the chrome yellow that covers much of the sheet. These areas include the NOANOA medallion at the top, the distant background where the hut is located, and the figures’ bodies. Since the artist wiped media from selected areas to ensure that the yellow medium was placed where intended, it is likely that a piece of glass was used so that he could see where he wished to remove the yellow ink. To achieve this degree of specificity, it is likely that Gauguin brushed the ink onto the glass. By placing the glass over the block, Gauguin could accurately locate and remove the yellow ink from the areas in which he did not want it to appear.

After the sheet of glass, acting as a tone block, was printed, a second layer of media was applied to the glass. Microscopic examination indicates that residual yellow ink that did not transfer to the paper remained on the glass and a second layer was applied directly on top of it in a second transfer. In this second layer of media, a golden yellow and orange predominate, with lesser amounts of green present as well (fig. 51.3.6). The predominant medium here has a crusty, lichen-like appearance that differs greatly from the fluid yellow-ink layer below (fig. 51.3.7). The dimensionality of the medium is more pronounced in raking light. Examination under magnification and gentle probing with a needle reveals that the medium has a waxy consistency, and, indeed, the oil-based medium was found to contain some beeswax and conifer resin (probably pine resin). The dimensional, thick, and cakey oil-based media appear as rounded islands that sit on top of the paper. The high points have been rubbed flat and exhibit sheen. In raking light, the edges of the islands of media reflect light and shimmer. There is an obvious vertical directionality to the transferred medium, indicative of rubbing in a vertical direction. It is clear that the media was burnished under pressure.

It is possible that Gauguin took advantage of the properties of the wax-and-resin-containing medium by applying it to the glass and then allowing it to cool and partially harden before transferring it to paper. When Gauguin placed the sheet of paper that now carried the yellow tone back on top of the glass and rubbed it, he transferred seemingly random islands of encrusted media throughout the sheet. However, close examination reveals that there is a denser application of the medium in the upper half of the sheet, especially along the left and right sides. Color variations likewise initially seem random, yet there is a greater concentration of green in the lower part of the tree and a greater concentration of orange in the skirt of the foreground figure. The general absence of this medium from the uppermost medallion and the upper half of the torso of the foreground figure are clearly specific exclusions and provide further evidence that glass was used, not only as the support to carry the media but as a means to accurately locate it.

Having applied the second layer of media, Gauguin proceeded to position the paper on top of the wood block that he had inked in black. Here, as in many of his impressions, the black ink was unevenly applied to the roller as evidenced by darker black vertical striations to the left, center, and right of the composition. Because the artist applied only light pressure using a hard roller, the black ink transferred primarily to the high points of the dimensional islands of colored media, so that the yellow base tone remained visible around them (fig. 51.3.8). The end result is a reticulated surface where halos of color appear around each isolated island of black.

In a fourth and final step, Gauguin returned to the print after it had dried and hand colored selected passages. Using reddish-brown watercolor he darkened the face, proper left shoulder, arm, and legs of the figure in the background. He used the same tone, applied with a dry brush, to darken the face, proper right arm, and a band of the skirt of the figure in the foreground while using black to selectively darken the legs (fig. 51.3.9). Ultimately, Gauguin worked in a deliberate manner to lay out zones of color, yet he left the visual end result of the mechanical transfer of media to chance. The artist’s approach was systematic; his materials and their application were well thought-out to achieve the desired tonal and textural variations evident in the work. What at first glance appears to be a spontaneously executed production is instead a well-considered methodology borne of an assessment of the materials, their diverse mechanical properties, and their distinctive appearance when transferred onto a paper surface.

In 1988 the print was treated locally to make small repairs along the edges using Japanese paper and wheat starch paste.

The print is in very good condition. It is irregularly shaped, with the lower left corner trimmed at an angle. Small fragments of the primary support extend past the secondary support and are very vulnerable to damage or loss. There is a diagonal incised line 8 cm long in the immediate foreground just above the bottom edge to the left. There is a clear, shiny accretion located 14 cm in from the right edge and 3 cm up from the bottom edge. Some foxing is visible in the primary support but is very much obscured by the yellow media in the print. It is readily visible under ultraviolet light. A collector’s stamp appears as a circular dent located 3 cm in from the right edge and 7 cm up from the bottom edge below the dog’s tail. The mount is foxed throughout. Under ultraviolet light the foxing appears as rounded, dark golden-yellow stains, and residual adhesives and papers fluoresce bright white.  
Harriet K. Stratis with the assistance of Mary Broadway

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">From the artist to Francisco “Paco” Durrio (1868–1940), Paris, between 1893 and 1895.

Left by Francisco “Paco” Durrio at Kunsthalle Basel for exhibition in 1928.

Walther Geiser (1897–1993), Basel, by Jan. 18, 1931.

Consigned by Walther Geiser to Lucas Lichtenhan (1897–1969), Basel, on Jan. 18, 1931.

Returned by Lucas Lichtenhan to Walther Geiser in 1936.

Sold by Walther Geiser to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.

Paris, Galeries Nationales du Grand Palais, Gauguin Tahiti, Sept 30, 2003–Jan. 19, 2004, cat. 107 (ill.); Boston, Museum of Fine Arts, Feb. 29–June 20, 2004.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Société du Salon d’Automne, Catalogue des ouvrages de peinture, sculpture, dessin, gravure, architecture et art décoratif, exh. cat. (Compagnie Française des Papiers-Monnaie, 1906), cat. 138.

Marcel Guérin, L’oeuvre gravé de Gauguin (H. Floury, 1927; Alan Wofsy Fine Arts, 1980), cat. 17.

Kunsthalle Basel, Paul Gauguin, 1848–1903, exh. cat. (Kunsthalle Basel, 1928), p. 25, cat. 114.

Kunsthalle Basel, Paul Gauguin, 1848–1903, exh. cat., 2nd ed. (Kunsthalle Basel, 1928), p. 30, cat. 224.

Galerien Thannhauser, Paul Gauguin, 1848–1903, introduction by W. Barth, exh. cat. (Galerien Thannhauser, 1928), p. 15, cat. 200.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Signed in wood block, upper center, printed in black ink: PGO

Inscribed in wood block, upper center, printed in white-line manner: NOANOA

Collector’s stamp lower right, encircled in black ink: W.G. / B

Inscribed upper left, in graphite: No. 5160

Inscribed upper right, in graphite: No. 17

Inscribed along left edge, center, in graphite: – 3 –

Inscribed in the artist’s hand, lower left, in pen and brown ink: 10 Mars / PG [0 has been changed to 5 and a second rs has been added on top of the rs in black ink]

Collector’s stamp center, encircled and upside down in black ink: W.G. / B

The media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (8–10×), and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm). The pigments in the printing inks and oil-based media were identified by XRF, Raman microspectroscopy, macro-XRF, and FTIR. The organic media containing beeswax and Pinaceae resin were identified by THM-Py-GCMS. The print was studied by means of photometric stereo.

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Among the group of impressions of Noa Noa (Fragrant) examined in the Art Institute’s collection and elsewhere, a previously undocumented state between the second and the third was discovered and described (see cat. 52.2, Technical Study); this brings the total number of states to four.

The locations of eight blocks from the Noa Noa Suite are known. Embossed into the verso of each is the trade name of the manufacturer, Kiessling. The manufacturer’s stamp reads: Kiessling / J Lacroix Suc / PARIS / D 089. Blocks for Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (cat. 55.1) and Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) (cat. 60.1) are in the Art Institute’s collection. The block for Noa Noa (cat. 51) is in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, and is described as fruitwood, possibly pearwood. The blocks for Te po (The Night) (cat. 52), Auti te pape (Women at the River) (cat. 59), and Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (cat. 56) are in the collection of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. The block for L’univers est créé (The Universe Is Being Created) (cat. 54) is in the Memorial Art Gallery, University of Rochester, New York. The block for Mahna no varua ino (The Devil Speaks) (cat. 57) resides in the Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Paris. Gauguin repurposed two blocks from the suite, Te atua (The God) (cat. 53) and Te faruru (Here We Make Love) (cat. 58), by cutting them down and using the backs for a series of smaller prints that he made during his last years in Paris and upon his return to Tahiti in 1895. Two of the segments from the block for Te faruru are in the Národní Galerie, Prague. The segments from the block used for Te atua (The God) are presently lost.

I am grateful to Peter Zegers for so generously sharing his insights into the Noa Noa Suite. See Peter Kort Zegers, “In the Kitchen with Paul Gauguin: Devising Recipes for a Symbolist Graphic Aesthetic,” in The Broad Spectrum: Studies in Materials, Techniques, and Conservation of Color on Paper, ed. Harriet K. Stratis and Britt Salvesen (Archetype, 2002), pp. 138–44.

It is possible that this oil-based medium, which does not resemble printing ink, came directly from the palette that Gauguin used for his paintings. He did not produce these prints in isolation from the artworks that he was producing in other media in his studio. Paintings analyzed for this publication were found to contain original wax coatings (see, for example, Te raau rahi [The Big Tree] [cat. 27]), and several publications cite Gauguin’s use of wax and resin in his paint mixtures. See, for example, Carol Christensen, “The Painting Materials and Techniques of Paul Gauguin,” Conservation Research, ed. Ross M. Merrill, Studies in the History of Art, Monograph Series 2, vol. 41 (National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., 1993), pp. 63–103.

Using the toolbar at the bottom right, any two images of the artwork may be selected for comparison by clicking the layers icon to the right of the slider bar. The slider bar may be moved to transition back and forth between the two chosen images. Where annotations are available, the jagged-line icon brings up a list of them, or colored lines that show the significant features visible in each image, which may be turned on or off in any combination. For example, the red annotation lines, associated with the natural-light image, trace some of the artwork’s key compositional features. When overlaid onto a technical image (X-ray, raking light, ultraviolet, etc.), the red outlines help the viewer to better observe how features in the technical image relate to or diverge from the artwork as seen with the naked eye. (When annotations are turned on, a legend appears in the upper right showing each color and its associated image type.) The circular-arrow icon returns the image to the default settings (natural light, full-image view, natural-light [red] annotation on). The four-arrow icon toggles between the view of the image in the page and a full-screen view of the image. In the upper right corner, the vertical slider bar may be moved to zoom into or out of the image; different parts of the image can be accessed by clicking and dragging within the image itself. The icon in the upper left corner opens a small view of the full image, within which a red box indicates the portion of the overall image being viewed when zooming is enabled.

When the lightbulb icon is yellow, you can change the direction of light illuminating the work of art. To turn off this function, click on the lightbulb icon. To zoom in or out of the work of art, use the zoom function in the upper right of the image viewer (plus/minus signs). To move the work of art in the viewer window, turn off the lightbulb and click and drag the work of art in the direction you would like it to move. To see the work of art full screen, click on the full-screen icon. To return to the original view, click on the return icon (semicircle with arrow).

This method of transfer is clearly the precursor to the watercolor and oil-transfer methods that Gauguin adopted moving forward (see Tahitian Landscape [cat. 68] and Nativity [Mother and Child Surrounded by Five Figures] for examples). See Peter Kort Zegers, “In the Kitchen with Paul Gauguin: Devising Recipes for a Symbolist Graphic Aesthetic,” in The Broad Spectrum: Studies in Materials, Techniques, and Conservation of Color on Paper, ed. Harriet K. Stratis and Britt Salvesen (Archetype, 2002), pp. 138–44.

Pigment analysis of the wax-and-resin-containing medium was carried on Te atua (The God) (cat. 53.4), L’univers est créé (The Universe Is Being Created) (cat. 54.3), and Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (cat. 55.3). Emerald green was identified in all of them. Visual examination of this example from the suite reveals that emerald green is present. The tonality of the green medium and its appearance on the paper is the same as those for which pigment analysis was conducted. Pigment analysis carried out by Céline Daher is gratefully acknowledged; Daher, XRF, macro-XRF, Raman microspectroscopy, and FTIR analytical results summary, Dec. 2015, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Art Institute of Chicago.

Edgar Degas owned prints from the Noa Noa Suite that were mounted on mottled blue paper. See Ann Dumas, “Degas and His Collection,” in Dumas, Colta Ives, Susan Alyson Stein, and Gary Tinterow, The Private Collection of Edgar Degas: A Summary Catalogue (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, 1997), p. 57. An impression of Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) mounted on mottled blue paper is in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York; the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, owns mounted impressions of Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) and Te po (The Night).

The reflectance transformation imaging (RTI)/photometric stereo research project was undertaken at the Northwestern University/Art Institute of Chicago Center for Scientific Studies in the Arts (NU-ACCESS), generously funded through a grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation. Xiang Huang, who spent countless hours assembling the RTI images that appear in this online catalogue, is especially acknowledged. See Oliver Cossairt, Xiang Huang, Nathan Matsuda, Harriet Stratis, Mary Broadway, Jack Tumblin, Greg Bearman, Eric Doehne, Aggelos Katsaggelos, and Marc Walton. “Surface shape studies of the art of Paul Gauguin,” 2015 Digital Heritage International Conference, ed. Gabriele Guidi, Juan Carlos Torres, Roberto Scopigno, and Holfer Graf, vol. 2 (IEEE, 2015), pp. 13–20, doi: 10.1109/DigitalHeritage.2015.7419447.

I am grateful to Peter Zegers for so generously sharing his observations concerning Gauguin’s use of glass and for his insights into the Noa Noa Suite. See Peter Kort Zegers, “In the Kitchen with Paul Gauguin: Devising Recipes for a Symbolist Graphic Aesthetic,” in The Broad Spectrum: Studies in Materials, Techniques, and Conservation of Color on Paper, ed. Harriet K. Stratis and Britt Salvesen (Archetype, 2002), pp. 138–44.

In many ways the carrier used to transfer media determines the visual qualities that are obtained once the media has been transferred onto a paper support. In this impression, because the bright-yellow medium appears to be of a thin, fluid consistency, it could not have been transferred from a paper carrier. The paper itself would have absorbed much more media than would have deposited in the transfer process, and the resulting transfer could not have been as distinct and media rich.

Analysis of the organic media using THM-Py-GCMS found it to be an oil-based medium with beeswax and Pinaceae resin present in different amounts in various prints. Céline Daher, THM-Py-GCMS analytical results summary, Dec. 2015, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Art Institute of Chicago.

Mary Cropley, Andrew W. Mellon Fellow in Paper Conservation, condition report, treatment record, and photographic documentation, Jan. 1988; Harriet K. Stratis, technical report and photographic documentation, June 1990; Kristi Dahm, condition report, Aug. 2003, all in conservation object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

Gauguin left Durrio several works on paper from his Parisian studio at 6, rue Vercingétorix, prior to his departure for his second trip to Tahiti in 1895. Scholarship is inconclusive as to whether Gauguin gave the works to Durrio as a gift or consigned them to Durrio for sale. González de Durana, Alzuri, and Amezaga, who have researched the relationship between the two artists, reason that the works were likely a gift, because the penniless Durrio was unable to serve as a trustworthy salesman and the works were seen as being of little value since Gauguin left them behind when he returned to Tahiti. See Javier González de Durana, Miriam Alzuri, and María Amezaga, Francisco Durrio (1868–1940): Sobre las huellas de Gauguin, exh. cat. (Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao, 2013), pp. 195–98, 221, no. 13. See also Société du Salon d’Automne, Catalogue des ouvrages de peinture, sculpture, dessin, gravure, architecture et art décoratif, exh. cat. (Compagnie Française des Papiers-Monnaie, 1906), cat. 138.

When Durrio loaned his Gauguin collection to the 1928 Kunsthalle Basel exhibition on Gauguin (see Exhibition History), he received a deposit of 100,000 francs as a guarantee for the return of his collection. Financial troubles forced Durrio to accept the cash deposit from the museum before the conclusion of the exhibition, forfeiting his property as a result. He could not raise the funds in enough time to purchase back his Gauguin collection before it was auctioned off by the Swiss managers of the show. We know nothing of these two people, but one of them could have been the director of the Kunsthalle Basel, Wilhelm Barth; someone with a role in the exhibitons in Basel-Berlin; or someone close to him. Javier González de Durana, Miriam Alzuri, and María Amezaga, Francisco Durrio (1868–1940): Sobre las huellas de Gauguin, exh. cat. (Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao, 2013), pp. 195–98.

See Javier González de Durana, Miriam Alzuri, and María Amezaga, Francisco Durrio (1868–1940): Sobre las huellas de Gauguin, exh. cat. (Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao, 2013), pp. 195–98. Noa Noa (Fragrant) from the Noa Noa Suite appears in the inventories of Geiser (no. 86-106, Jan. 18, 1931, Holzschnitte, and no. 68–89, Dec. 24, 1931, as Gravures sur bois, all listed as a set of woodcuts); photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago. The collection was purchased in Basel after Durrio failed to return the cash deposit on the works loaned for the 1928 exhibition. Walther Geiser’s collector stamp (not in Lugt) is on the verso.

Geiser, who purchased the collection, consigned it to Lucas Lichtenhan for sale on January 18, 1931, as written out in a signed contract; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

Geiser, as owner of the collection, consigned it to Lucas Lichtenhan for sale on January 18, 1931, but the print didn’t sell so it was returned to Geiser after they ended their contract in 1936. Photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

The works in the Paco Durrio, and later Walther Geiser, collection of wood-block prints in the collection of the Art Institute of Chicago have inscriptions on the verso that were deciphered as the order in which they were exhibited and presented in the catalogue for the 1906 Salon d’automne at the Grand Palais des Champs-Élysées. This print is inscribed with the number 3, the third print in the “Gravures sur bois” section of the exhibition, which corresponds to entry no. 138, “Noa-Noa.”

There are two editions of this exhibition catalogue. In the first edition, the exhibition dates are listed as July–August 1928, and the Art Institute’s print is given as cat. 114. See Kunsthalle Basel, Paul Gauguin, 1848–1903, exh. cat. (Kunsthalle Basel, 1928), p. 25, cat. 114. In the second edition, the exhibition dates are listed as July–September 9, 1928, and the Art Institute’s print is given as cat. 224. See Kunsthalle Basel, Paul Gauguin, 1848–1903, exh. cat., 2nd ed. (Kunsthalle Basel, 1928), p. 30, cat. 224.

Collector’s stamp of Walther Geiser, Basel (not in Lugt).

Collector’s stamp of Walther Geiser, Basel (not in Lugt).

fig. 51.3.4 Gauguin’s Noa Noa (Fragrant) (1893/94) with annotations identifying the pigments and the organic media, the areas selected for analysis, and the scientific methods used in their identification. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.255.

fig. 51.3.5 Gauguin’s Noa Noa (Fragrant) (1893/94) (top left). Elemental mapping identified pigments and determined media distribution across the sheet. White areas indicate the presence of, top right, chromium (present in chrome yellow); bottom left, mercury (indicative of vermilion pigment); and bottom right, copper (present in a copper-containing green pigment). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.255.

fig. 51.3.3 RTI image of Gauguin’s Noa Noa (Fragrant) (1893/94). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.255. Interactive image.

fig. 51.3.6 Left, detail of Gauguin’s Noa Noa (Fragrant) (1893/94) with a red rectangle around area of interest. Center left and center right, stereomicrographs. Right, high-magnification stereomicrograph showing the black ink printed over the transferred golden-yellow and orange dimensional oil-based media, over the more fluid underlying yellow printing ink. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.255.

fig. 51.3.7 Left, detail of Gauguin’s Noa Noa (Fragrant) (1893/94) with a red rectangle around area of interest. Center and right, stereomicrographs showing the transferred golden-yellow, orange, and green dimensional oil-based media. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.255.

fig. 51.3.8 Left, detail of Gauguin’s Noa Noa (Fragrant) (1893/94) with a red rectangle around area of interest. Center and right, stereomicrographs showing the black ink sitting on top of dimensional islands of colored media. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.255.

fig. 51.3.9 Left, detail of Gauguin’s Noa Noa (Fragrant) (1893/94) with a red rectangle around area of interest. Center, stereomicrograph. Right, high-magnification stereomicrograph showing the reddish-brown and black hand-applied media in the arm of the figure. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.255.

fig. 51.3.2 Gauguin’s Noa Noa (Fragrant) (1893/94). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.255. Interactive image.
